item.paragraph:
Formatting of this note is different from the original.
Images from the original note were not included.
Kaiser Advice/Appointment Line: 510-795-3055
Your care was provided by: Davenport, Joshua Andrew (M.D.)
You were treated for the following: alcohol intoxication
Your follow up plan: Please call the Department of Adult and Family Medicine : (510) 248-3055 to schedule an appointment within 2 days for reevaluation.
Instructions about your care:
As discussed, your heart rate is still very high. This is likely due to dehydration from too much alcohol.
You declined IV hydration and monitoring in the ER.
Please make sure you drink lots of fluids/water at home.
Return to the ER for any changes in behavior, any pain or fever.
Alcohol Abuse
Alcoholic drinks are harmful when you have too many of them. There is no set number of drinks that defines too much. Drinking that disrupts your life or your health is called alcohol abuse. Alcohol abuse can hurt your relationships with others. You may lose friends, a spouse, or even your job. You may be abusing alcohol if any of the following are true for you:
· Duties at home or with child care suffer because of drinking.
· Duties at work or in school suffer because of drinking.
· You have missed work or school because of drinking.
· You use alcohol while driving or operating machinery.
· You have legal problems such as arrests due to drinking.
· You keep drinking even though it causes serious problems in your life.
Health effects
Alcohol abuse causes health problems. Sometimes this can happen after only drinking a “little." There is no set number of drinks or amount of alcohol that defines too much. The more you drink at one time, and the more often you drink determine both the short-term and long-term health effects. It affects all parts of your body and your health, including your:
· Brain. Alcohol is a central nervous system depressant. It can damage parts of the brain that affect your balance, memory, thinking, and emotions. It can cause memory loss, blackouts, depression, agitation, sleep cycle changes, and seizures. These changes may or may not be reversible.
· Heart and vascular system. Alcohol affects multiple areas. It can damage heart muscle causing cardiomyopathy, which is a weakening and stretching of the heart muscle. This can lead to trouble breathing, an irregular heartbeat, atrial fibrillation, leg swelling, and heart failure. Alcohol use makes the blood vessels stiffen causing hypertension (high blood pressure). All of these problems increase your risk of having heart attacks or strokes.
· Liver. Alcohol causes fat to build up in the liver, affecting its normal function. This increases the risk for hepatitis, leading to abdominal pain, appetite loss, jaundice, bleeding problems, liver fibrosis, and cirrhosis. This, in turn, can affect your ability to fight off infections, and can cause diabetes. The liver changes prevent it from removing toxins in your blood that can cause encephalopathy which may show with confusion, altered level of consciousness, personality changes, memory loss, seizures, coma, and death.
· Pancreas. Alcohol can cause inflammation of the pancreas, or pancreatitis. This can cause abdominal pain, fever, and diabetes.
· Immune system. Alcohol weakens your immune system in a number of ways. It suppresses your immune system making it harder to fight infections and colds. It also increases the chance of getting pneumonia and tuberculosis.
· Cancer. Alcohol is a risk factor for developing cancer of the mouth, esophagus, pharynx, larynx, liver, and breast.
· Sexual function. Alcohol can lead to sexual problems.
Home care
The following guidelines will help you deal with alcohol abuse:
· Admit you have a problem with alcohol.
· Ask for help from your health care provider and trusted family members or close friends.
· Get help from people trained in dealing with alcohol abuse. This may be individual counseling or group therapy, or it may be a supervised alcohol treatment program.
· Join a self-help group for alcohol abuse such as Alcoholics Anonymous (AA).
· Avoid people who abuse alcohol or tempt you to drink.
Follow-up care
Follow up as advised by the doctor or our staff. Contact these groups to get help:
· Alcoholics Anonymous (AA): Go to www.aa.org or check the phone book for meetings near you.
· National Alcohol and Substance Abuse Information Center (NASAIC): 800-784-6776 www.addictioncareoptions.com
· National Council on Alcoholism and Drug Dependence (NCADD): 800-NCA-CALL (622-2255) www.ncadd.org
· Al-Anon: 888-4AL-ANON (425-2666) www.al-anon.org
Call 911
Call 911 if any of these occur:
· Trouble breathing or slow irregular breathing
· Chest pain
· Sudden weakness on one side of your body or sudden trouble speaking
· Heavy bleeding or vomiting blood
· Very drowsy or trouble awakening
· Fainting or loss of consciousness
· Rapid heart rate
· Seizure
When to seek medical care
Get prompt medical attention if you have:
· Confusion
· Hallucinations (seeing, hearing, or feeling things that aren’t there)
· Pain in your upper abdomen that gets worse
· Repeated vomiting or black or tarry stools
· Severe shakiness
© 2000-2015 The StayWell Company, LLC. 780 Township Line Road, Yardley, PA 19067. All rights reserved. This information is not intended as a substitute for professional medical care. Always follow your healthcare professional's instructions.
If you are a Kaiser member and do not have a doctor, call Member Outreach at 1-510-675-2663.
Questions about our Medical Financial Assistance and Discount Payment Policies? Please contact the Medical Financial Assistance Central Unit at 1-866-399-7696.
We provide a list of charges for our medical procedures and services in accordance with California law. Information can be found at www.kp.org/hospitalcharges or you may call 1-866-468-0006.

item.caption: CHRISTINA AKINNUSOTU RN - 02/16/2020 4:10 AM PST
item.paragraph:
Formatting of this note might be different from the original.
Parent request to take patient home. In spite of HR at 129. Pt OOB to restroom x 1 with steady gait, tolerated 1000 ml of water. Patient able follow to commands and family at bedside.
Electronically signed by CHRISTINA AKINNUSOTU RN at 02/16/2020 4:44 AM PST

item.caption: CHRISTINA AKINNUSOTU RN - 02/16/2020 3:10 AM PST
item.paragraph:
Formatting of this note might be different from the original.
Patient resting in bed alert and calm. Pending urine sample. Updates parent in the waiting room on patient care. Per mother of patient EMS was called when patient began to cough consistently at home and concern for choking incident, EMS was called.
Electronically signed by CHRISTINA AKINNUSOTU RN at 02/16/2020 3:52 AM PST

item.caption: DEANNA LORRIN BARROSO RN - 02/16/2020 2:36 AM PST
item.paragraph:
Formatting of this note is different from the original.
SEPSIS SCREENING TOOL
2 SIRS CRITERIA: SUSPECTED INFECTION:
Temp ‹ 96.8 or › 100.4 F Urinary frequency, burning, odor
HR › 90/min Cough, SOB, yellow/green phlegm
RR › 20/min Abd pain, RUQ pain, RLQ pain
WBC › 12K or ‹ 4k or › 10% Bands Open Wounds, cellulites, abscess
Altered Mental State
OR SBP less than or equal to 90
2 SIRS plus suspected infection = positive screen
SBP < 90 plus suspected infection = positive screen
POSITIVE SCREEN: NO
IF POSITIVE SCREEN, ALERT MD IMMEDIATELY FOR A LACTATE ORDER (PREFERABLY I-STAT) AND/OR IV FLUIDS ORDER
Electronically signed by DEANNA LORRIN BARROSO RN at 02/16/2020 2:36 AM PST

item.caption: JOSHUA ANDREW DAVENPORT MD - 02/16/2020 2:36 AM PST
item.paragraph:
Formatting of this note is different from the original.
Emergency Room Note: first contact 2:37 AM JOSHUA ANDREW DAVENPORT MD
CC: alcohol intoxication
History obtained from parents, EMS, a good historian. All of the MSE, vital signs, medications, & allergies have been reviewed
HPI: Manav Agarwal is a 33 Y male who presents with ETOH intox.
Lives with parents, hx of depression, anxiety, ETOH abuse.
Patient drank a 750 cc bottle of Vodka tonight.
Began to have dry heaving and was not responding to parents; EMS called.
Patient alert, awake when EMS arrived, was not answering questions.
Tachycardia noted by EMS.
On arrival, patient admits to drinking vodka tonight.
Denies other drugs.
Denies SI or HI.
Parents dont have any knowledge of drugs available to patient.
Symptoms are moderate.
Patient Active Problem List:
ANXIETY
OVERWEIGHT
DEPRESSION, UNSPECIFIED
HYPERCHOLESTEROLEMIA
PREDIABETES
ALCOHOL PREVENTION COUNSELING
BENZODIAZEPINE OVERDOSE
LACTIC ACIDOSIS
HYPERLIPIDEMIA
ELEVATED LIVER FUNCTION TEST
Social History
Tobacco Use
• Smoking status: Never Smoker
• Smokeless tobacco: Never Used
Substance Use Topics
• Alcohol use: Yes
Alcohol/week: 6.0 standard drinks
Types: 6 Standard drinks or equivalent per week
• Drug use: No

Problem Relation Age of Onset

• Diabetes Father
• Heart Disease Father 55
• Hypertension Father

• Healthy Sister

• Dextroamphetamine-Amphetamine (ADDERALL) 10 mg Oral Tab Take 1 to 2 tablets by mouth 2 times a day 100 0
Allergies: Patient has no known allergies.
Review of Systems:
Constitutional: negative for fever and negative for chills
Cardiovascular: Negative for chest pain
Respiratory: negativ e for shortness of breath
Patient Vitals for the past 24 hrs:
Temp Temp Source Pulse BP Resp SpO2 O2 Delivery
02/16/20 0234 98.2 °F (36.8 °C) Oral 136 133/99 16 97 % RA-Room Air
Physical Examination:
BP 133/99 | Pulse 136 | Temp 98.2 °F (36.8 °C) | Resp 16 | Wt 65.4 kg (144 lb 1.6 oz) | SpO2 97% | BMI 22.56 kg/m²
Physical Examination:
General appearance - vital signs reviewed and alert, well appearing, and in no distress. + AOB
Mental status - alert, oriented to person, place, and time, normal mood, behavior, and thought processes
Head - atraumatic
Eyes - no photophobia
Mouth - MMM
Neck - no JVD. No tracheal deviation
Respiratory - clear to auscultation, no wheezes, rales or rhonchi, symmetric air entry, no tachypnea, retractions or cyanosis. Equal breath sounds B/L.
Cardiovascular - Tachycardia and regular rhythm, normal S1, S2, no murmurs or rubs
Abdomen - soft, nontender, nondistended, no masses or organomegaly
Neurological - motor grossly intact to all 4 extremities.
Extremities - no edema to extremities
Skin - No cyanosis.
Labs/Imaging/Tests:
Results for orders placed or performed during the hospital encounter of 02/16/20
ALCOHOL (ETOH) LEVEL, AUTOMATED ANALYZER
Result Value Ref Range
Ethanol,bld,qn 451 (AA) mg/dL
Ethanol %, blood 0.45 %
ACETAMINOPHEN LEVEL, AUTOMATED ANALYZER
Result Value Ref Range
Acetaminophen <10 0 - 30 ug/mL
SALICYLATE LEVEL, AUTOMATED ANALYZER
Result Value Ref Range
Salicylates, qn <3 <=30 mg/dL
EKG: (my reading) sinus tachycardia, Rate- 138 bpm, QRS- Normal, ST/T segments- Normal.
Medical Decision Making/ED Course:
33 y/o M p/w symptoms c/w etoh intox.
Awake, alert, responsive.
Tachycardia noted.
IVF, zofran, EKG, ETOH and tox labs.
Will reassess.
Parents in waiting room.
4:10 AM
Mom and Dad want to take patient home.
He has a steady gait. Is awake and oriented.
Mom and dad aware that he has very high ETOH level in blood and is likely dehydrated.
I advised patient stay in ED and get more IVF and make sure his HR improves.
However parents (and patient) want to go home.
They insist he will drink lots of water.
Good return precautions given.
Although I strive to keep an accurate timeline, due to the dynamic nature of emergency patient care, the above timestamps may not reflect the actual time of intervention or interpretation of results.
I have confirmed the presence of the below clinical diagnoses, which were considered in the current and ongoing care of the patient. At the time of this visit, the medical record indicates, and/or the patient states, that there are no changes in these conditions unless otherwise noted. As treatment warrants, the patient has been advised to follow up with PCP or appropriate specialist.
ANXIETY (Chronic)
OVERWEIGHT (Chronic)
DEPRESSION, UNSPECIFIED (Chronic)
HYPERCHOLESTEROLEMIA (Chronic)
HYPERLIPIDEMIA (Chronic)
Diagnosis:
ICD-10-CM

2. TACHYCARDIA R00.0
Consult: none
Condition: stable
Disposition: home
Electronically signed by JOSHUA ANDREW DAVENPORT MD at 02/16/2020 4:13 AM PST
